awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: The chemistry of lignin's photochemical transformation in the environment: implications for global carbon cycling
awd_abstract_narration:
In this project funded by the Environmental Chemical Sciences program of the Chemistry Division, Drs. Patrick Hatcher of Old Dominion University, Satish Myneni of Princeton University, and Christopher Hadad of The Ohio State University employ a multidisciplinary approach to study lignin, a complex organic polymer deposited in the cell walls of many plants, making them rigid and woody.  Lignin is an Earth abundant organic biopolymer that provides the starting point to recycle carbon from plants into the environment.  In this project, the researchers explore pathways for the molecular rearrangement of lignin to form the molecules present in soil, water and sediments.  A postdoctoral associate, graduate students, and several undergraduates are trained to combine geochemistry, fundamental molecular studies, advanced analytical techniques, and modern computational modeling of complex reaction pathways.  This training provides these future scientists with an interdisciplinary experience.  Undergraduate and high school engagement, including diversified recruitment, is included.

In this research project, lignin is subjected to oxidative degradation by reactive oxygen species (ROS) to partially reorganize and polymerize to form humic substances. These humic substances may effectively sequester lignin-derived carbon in contrast to the theory that lignin is completely oxidized to carbon dioxide and contribute to greenhouse warming. This research subjects both synthesized and natural lignin to oxidative decomposition by ROS in the presence of aqueous iron species, mimicking environmental oxidation. The study employs Fourier transform ion cyclotron resonance mass spectrometry, multidimensional liquids and solids NMR, and synchrotron-based X-ray absorption spectroscopy to discern molecular transformation pathways.  The research also provides new information regarding both the pathways and magnitude with which photochemistry and ROS affect the cycling of terrestrial carbon among Earth's large reservoirs of carbon, impacting the chemistry of terrestrial systems and oceans.

por.por_cntn:
All natural waters- both surface and subsurface waters on land, and ocean water- contain organic molecules derived from various biological processes. Some of these molecules are released by organisms to obtain nutrients, whereas others come from biomass weathering. The concentration, composition, structure, and chemistry of these molecules vary with the location, climate, and the type of weathering condition, and play an important role in the solubility and transport of nutrients and contaminants and thus the water quality.

Organic molecules in soils and freshwater streams are mostly derived from plants, and consist of biopolymers, such as lignin, tannin, cellulose and proteins. Some of these molecules are highly soluble and enter streams, whereas others stay in soil because of low solubility or stay adsorbed on soil minerals. While interactions with soil microorganisms destabilize these interactions, some of these molecules can be protected from such microbial alteration by soil minerals. Once in water, sunlight can interact with the molecules that are photo-sensitive and break them to small molecules or transform them to gaseous carbon dioxide. In the process, some of the organic carbon in streams can flocculate and exist as particulates in water column or precipitate out of water column and become part of riverine sediments, whereas the pool remaining in water column can end up in oceans.

Intellectual Merit:

The goal of our study is to evaluate how stable plant biopolymer, lignin, undergoes transformation when exposed to sunlight in freshwater environments. At what rate these transformations occur, and which variables control the rates? What are the typical breakdown products? The study is in collaboration with researchers from Old Dominion University (ODU) and The Ohio State University (OSU). Researchers at ODU synthesized the lignin polymer used in our studies, and OSU researchers observed the transformations using theoretical approaches.

Laboratory studies were conducted to test the impact of sunlight on the transformation of both synthetic lignin and natural dissolved organic molecules (DOM) from stream waters from protected regions in conferral (Pine Barrens) and deciduous forests as well as agricultural lands in New Jersey. We also examined the impact of soluble iron (and chemical form of iron) on the breakdown of these organic molecules. These studies are conducted using a solar simulator, and the conditions were set in such a way that the samples were exposed to mid-latitude sunlight characteristics. The laboratory studies were conducted for 7 days, which is equivalent to sunlight exposure for 14 normal days in mid-latitudes. We employed multiple spectroscopy methods to characterize the organic molecules as they undergo reactions with sunlight.

Our findings suggest that more than 90% of the organic molecules is lost, mostly in the form of gaseous form and a small pool in the form of particulate matter within 14 days of normal exposure to sunlight. In addition the remaining fraction of organic molecules is broken down to small molecules that do not absorb sunlight effectively. We also found that the additions of soluble iron enhanced the rate at which these transformations occur. While the natural stream water samples have some iron, synthetic lignin needed this soluble iron for accelerated breakdown, implicating the role of iron in the photochemical breakdown of biopolymers. Both synthetic lignin and DOM from stream waters showed the same patterns. 

In summary, Our results point in the direction that the light sensitive molecules are highly labile in the water column, and the ability of organic molecules to react with chlorine or dissolved metals go down significantly after a prolonged exposure to sunlight.

Broader Impacts: 

Results from our studies are important for understanding how organic molecules in streams, leaked during soil weathering in forests because of climatic conditions and land management practices, can either be converted to gaseous forms and released into the atmosphere or broken down to smaller molecules because of photochemical reactions. If the molecules exist in the water column for 14 days in mid-latitudinal streams, a large fraction of these molecules would be converted to gaseous form. The remaining molecules can be part of water, precipitate out of water column or end up getting transported to oceans. The molecules we are identifying during these photochemical reactions are important during disinfection (or chlorination) of stream water for drinking purposes, and their ability to react and transport various contaminants.Our preliminary studies on agriculture runoff show that they follow similar patters as the DOM in pristine streams; however nature of organic carbon and their relative sensitivity to sunlight differ, and this is an active area of research in our laboratory. 

This project has supported 3 graduate students (one fully, and the other two partially during the Covid lockdown) in conducting the proposed studies, and 5 undergraduate students in pursuing senior and junior independent research projects. In addition, materials from these studies are used in teaching different courses (environmental geochemistry, soil chemistry and materials chemistry).
